questions.question: How does a neuron determine whether to generate an action potential when it receives a mix of excitatory and inhibitory inputs from multiple synapses?

options.A: The neuron sums the excitatory and inhibitory postsynaptic potentials over time and across inputs; if the net depolarization at the axon hillock reaches threshold, an action potential is triggered; otherwise it is not.
options.B: The neuron fires as long as any single excitatory input alone reaches the threshold, ignoring inhibitory inputs.
options.C: Inhibitory inputs always cancel excitatory inputs completely, preventing any action potential.
options.D: The neuron’s action potential depends only on the overall rate of neurotransmitter release into the synaptic cleft, not on membrane potential.

questions.question: How does representing second-order uncertainty—i.e., a probability density over first-order probabilities—change how we compute expected value and assess risk in decision making, and why is this representation particularly relevant for subjective logic?

options.A: It replaces the uncertain probability with a single most-likely value and uses that to compute the expected payoff, effectively ignoring second-order uncertainty.
options.B: It introduces a density over the first-order probability p, so the expected payoff is computed by averaging over p (e.g., E[payoff] = ∫ E[payoff|p] f(p) dp), which also broadens the induced risk due to uncertainty about p and aligns with how subjective logic represents beliefs.
options.C: It converts all uncertainty into a fixed variance of outcomes, leaving the underlying probabilities unchanged.
options.D: It makes the decision depend only on the average outcome, rendering the distribution of p and the associated uncertainty irrelevant.

questions.question: In a standard hypothesis-testing framework, you fix the significance level alpha at 0.05 and collect a larger sample. Which statement best explains how this change affects Type I and Type II errors and why?

options.A: Type I error rate increases with sample size; Type II error also increases, because more data creates more opportunities to reject the null regardless of truth.
options.B: Type I error rate remains about 0.05 (assuming model assumptions hold), while Type II error decreases because larger samples reduce sampling variability and increase the power to detect true effects.
options.C: Type I error rate decreases to near zero with larger samples; Type II error remains the same, because more data makes the null easier to disprove but cannot change false negatives.
options.D: Both Type I and Type II error rates decrease proportionally to the square root of the sample size, as more data makes decisions more accurate.

questions.question: Why do emergent properties of ecosystems require analyzing the system as a whole rather than studying a single species in isolation?

options.B: Because interactions among species (e.g., predation, competition, mutualism) and feedbacks with the abiotic environment create complex, non-additive effects that only appear when the system is analyzed as a whole.

options.D: Because energy flow through ecosystems is strictly linear, so analyzing one species yields all patterns.

options.D: Genetic drift operates only on non-heritable traits and thus has no impact on evolution in small populations.

options.A: Because effectors must keep pushing toward the set point regardless of the current state, which demonstrates positive feedback.
options.B: Because once the variable nears the set point, the control center shuts down entirely, showing feedforward control.
options.C: Because the effector’s stimulus diminishes as the variable returns to the set point, reducing the target output and stabilizing the system, which is negative feedback.
options.D: Because receptors directly reconfigure the set point itself, creating a new baseline and demonstrating adaptive feedback.

questions.question: Why do emergent properties arise in complex systems from the interactions of components, and what does this imply for explaining the system's behavior?

options.A: Because the global pattern is just a simple sum of individual component properties, enabling straightforward reduction to parts.
options.B: Because nonlinear interactions among components generate new organization and constraints at the system level, so the system's behavior cannot be fully explained by looking at components in isolation.
options.C: Because the properties of the system come entirely from the environment; the component rules are irrelevant.
options.D: Because once you know the initial conditions, the emergent property is predetermined and can be predicted by applying the component rules sequentially.

questions.question: A small block of mass m slides downhill on a perfectly smooth track under gravity from height h1 to a lower height h2 (h2 < h1). There are no nonconservative forces doing work. options.C: An external agent must inject energy as the block descends to balance gravity's pull, ensuring speed increases but momentum stays constant.

options.B: Because speakers deploy variants as indexical signals to align with audience expectations and social identities, so context (status, age, group membership) motivates variant choice.
options.C: Because grammar rules universally enforce a single variant per context, regardless of who is present or the setting.
options.D: Because exposure to media determines fixed form usage, with little influence from immediate social cues.

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, suppose the supply curve shifts to the right due to a fall in production costs, while the demand curve remains unchanged. Which explanation best describes why the new equilibrium price is lower and the equilibrium quantity is higher?

options.A: Because consumers now value the good more, causing demand to increase and push price downward.
options.B: Because producers can sell more at any price, they force the price down until inventories are cleared.
options.C: Because at the original price, quantity supplied exceeded quantity demanded (a surplus); to eliminate the surplus, price must fall, which increases quantity demanded and reduces quantity supplied until Qd = Qs, yielding a higher quantity and a lower price.
options.D: Because a rightward shift in supply creates a government-mandated lower price that applies regardless of demand.

concepts_tested: Concept 1: Market equilibrium and market-clearing price/quantity (the intersection of supply and demand where Qd = Qs and price adjusts to clear the market).

Concept 3: How shifts in supply (e.g., due to changes in production costs) affect equilibrium price and quantity (left/right shifts and the resulting price/quantity changes).

options.A: It shifts bargaining power toward employers by constraining union activities, making agreements less enforceable.

questions.question: In a competitive labor market where wages are determined by supply and demand, why does an increase in demand for a certain skill generally raise the equilibrium wage, and what does this imply about the resulting allocation of labor?

options.A: Because the wage serves as a price signal that coordinates the two sides; higher demand increases the wage and attracts more workers with that skill until the quantity supplied equals demand, leading to an efficient allocation of labor.
options.B: Because wages are determined by bargaining power alone, so higher demand transfers surplus to profits and does not change the wage; labor allocation remains fixed.
options.C: Because higher demand causes employers to hire only a few preferred workers at higher wages, reducing overall employment but increasing wages for a select group; this misallocates labor.
options.D: Because government price controls push wages upward when demand rises, which preserves social equity but distorts signals.

questions.question: In the standard rational labor supply framework, a higher wage rate affects hours worked through two opposing channels: the substitution effect (leisure becomes more expensive relative to consumption, pushing toward more work) and the income effect (higher income allows more leisure, pushing toward less work). options.A: The substitution effect always dominates, so higher wages always increase hours worked.
options.B: The income effect always dominates, so higher wages always decrease hours worked.
options.C: The substitution and income effects can push hours in opposite directions; the net change depends on which effect dominates for the individual’s preferences.
options.D: Wage changes have no impact on hours worked.

concepts_tested: Concept 1: Rational labor supply decision — workers choose how much to work based on wage, leisure, and utility to maximize lifetime utility.

questions.question: Why does extracting a renewable resource faster than its natural replenishment make it effectively non-renewable on human timescales?

options.A: Because the resource stock declines over time when removal exceeds replenishment, so the usable amount cannot be restored within the planning horizon.
options.B: Because replenishment only occurs during specific seasons, making the renewability depend on timing.
options.C: Because any replenishment guarantees unlimited supply regardless of extraction.
options.D: Because replenishment rates can always be increased to match any extraction rate with technology.

questions.question: In the basic tragedy of the commons mechanism, why does unfettered access to a finite resource tend to produce overuse?

options.B: The resource regenerates faster as more users extract it, encouraging overuse.

options.D: External enforcement is always perfect, so overuse cannot occur without regulation.

questions.question: Why does randomization in experimental design improve the validity of causal inferences, and how does it interact with subsequent data analysis to support valid conclusions about a treatment effect?

options.A: Randomization makes treatment assignment independent of subject characteristics in expectation, so observed differences between groups can be attributed to the treatment rather than confounding; this supports valid interpretation of statistical tests and confidence intervals under the null hypothesis.
options.B: Randomization guarantees perfect balance of all covariates in every experiment, so the observed difference is exactly the true causal effect, making statistical testing unnecessary.
options.C: Randomization only increases the sample size and statistical power, with no effect on bias or the interpretation of results.
options.D: Randomization ensures p-values will be small whenever there is a real effect, regardless of data quality or variability.

questions.question: Why does diffraction data enable determination of atomic positions and electron density in a crystal, and what fundamental limitation must be overcome to obtain a unique electron-density map?

options.A: Because measured diffraction intensities directly give the electron density at reciprocal-space points, so no additional information is needed.
options.B: Because diffraction experiments measure the amplitudes of structure factors |F(hkl)|, but the corresponding phases φ(hkl) are not observed; without these phases, the inverse Fourier transform cannot uniquely reconstruct electron density, so phasing methods are required to estimate the phases.
options.C: Because diffraction only indicates where atoms are located, not how their electrons are distributed, so you must assume a fixed electron density profile for each atom.
options.D: Because electron density can be inferred solely from stoichiometry and crystal symmetry, independent of diffraction data.

questions.question: According to the identical elements theory, why is transfer from a training task to a different context more likely when the contexts share common elements?

questions.question: Why can a theoretical physics framework progress even when no new experiments are immediately available, and how does this illustrate the difference between a physical theory and pure mathematics?

options.A: It can progress by providing a coherent, empirically grounded framework that both fits existing observations and yields novel, testable predictions for future experiments; in contrast, pure mathematics advances solely through deductive reasoning from axioms without requiring empirical confirmation.

questions.question: In two-dimensional geometry, why does the presence of a line of symmetry (an axis of symmetry) guarantee achirality for a bounded figure?

questions.question: How do social entities such as corporations, money, or social roles come to exist and exert real causal influence that cannot be captured by simply summing up individuals’ actions or beliefs?

options.A: They emerge purely from the aggregation of individuals’ beliefs, so the entity vanishes when beliefs change.
options.B: They are constituted by constitutive rules and shared intentions (collective intentionality), reinforced by material practices and institutions, which generate institutional facts with real causal powers.

questions.question: How does multiplexing enable multiple concurrent communication sessions to share a single transmission medium, and why does this arrangement prevent interference between those sessions?

options.A: By allocating distinct, non-overlapping resources—such as time slots in time-division multiplexing, or frequency/wavelength bands in frequency- or wavelength-division multiplexing—to different sessions, so each session transmits in its own resource and signals stay separate.
options.B: By sending each session's data in a randomized order and relying on statistical separation at the receiver, which would not truly guarantee separation.
options.C: By stacking all sessions into the same continuous signal and using powerful error-correcting codes to separate them at the receiver, which would not prevent overlap.
options.D: By duplicating the medium for each session so that only one session uses the medium at a time, which defeats the purpose of sharing.

questions.question: How does kin selection via inclusive fitness explain why prosocial behavior tends to be stronger toward close relatives, and what is a central boundary condition that it struggles to explain on its own?
